questions.question: ………………………….. the existence of antidrug laws, drug dealers persist in selling drugs illegally.
questions.description: We need a preposition before a noun. Although is used before a clause.

questions.question: ………………………… we have anti-drug laws, drug dealers continue to sell narcotics illegally.
questions.description: We use although to introduce a clause.

questions.question: The writer ………………………. that global warming is a major threat to the planet.
questions.description: We use the simple present to talk about opinions.

questions.question: ………………………… my childhood was peaceful, my adulthood is very hectic and stressful.
questions.description: We use while to connect two contrasting ideas.

questions.question: ……………………….. I get sunburn quite easily, I don’t sunbathe.
questions.description: Since can introduce the reason or cause.

questions.question: ………………………….. I studied at university I sold burgers.
questions.description: We can use while to talk about two situations that happen at the same time.

questions.question: The schools cancelled the classes after the thunderstorm ………………………….. students could be safe.
questions.description: We use so that to express intention or purpose.

questions.question: ……………………………. his long legs, he is a good basketball player.
questions.description: All of these can be used to indicate the reason.

questions.question: Companies don’t want to invest in countries where taxes are high. ………………………… increasing taxes will affect the economy.
questions.description: Therefore is a transitional adverb. It does not connect two clauses. So is a conjunction. It connects two clauses.

questions.question: Companies don’t want to invest in countries where taxes are high ………………………… increasing taxes will affect the economy.
questions.description: So is a coordinating conjunction that connects two clauses of equal rank.

questions.question: ………………………. companies don’t want to invest in countries where taxes are high, increasing taxes will affect the economy.
questions.description: Both since and because can give the reason for something.

questions.question: I enjoy reading books ………………………. motivate me.
questions.description: The relative pronoun that can refer to both people and things.
